units.title: Suppress mesoderm-derived immune cells in organoid culture
units.text: the organoid cul- ture method suppresses mesoderm-derived immune cell/microg- lia presence54 to achieve a more consistent forebrain identity and cell composition.
units.rationale: Describes a step to reduce immune cell contamination for consistent organoid identity.

units.title: Address astroglia- and neuron-dependent pathologies without immune response
units.text: This allowed us to specifically address initial astroglia- and neuron-dependent pathologies without immune or secondary inflammatory responses.
units.rationale: Specifies the experimental focus enabled by the culture method.

units.title: Supplement ALI-COs with microglia/allogeneic immune cells
units.text: supplementation of ALI-COs with microglia/allogeneic immune cells could address immune-related pathogenesis in ALS/FTD in the future55.
units.rationale: Proposes a future experimental addition to model immune interactions.

units.title: Slice organoids to improve nutrition and reduce necrotic core
units.text: the slicing of prematurity organoids may improve nutrition, suppressing the necrotic core that often features in whole organoids.
units.rationale: Suggests a procedural modification to enhance organoid viability.

units.title: Use adjacent slices as control–treatment pairs
units.text: two adjacent slices derived from the same organoid could serve as a control–treatment pair, increasing the confidence in analyzing drug-related effects.
units.rationale: Provides a strategy for paired experimental controls.

units.title: Partial pharmacological rescue in patient-specific organoids
units.text: The partial pharmacological rescue of early protein homeostasis- and DNA damage-related pathogenesis in our patient-specific organoids illustrates how C9 CO slices can be used for personalized and broader drug discovery strategies.
units.rationale: Highlights a rescue experiment that demonstrates the utility of the slice model.
